message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are typical for postpartum blues, which is a mild and transient mood disorder that affects up to 85% of women in the first few weeks after childbirth. The symptoms usually resolve within 10 days to 2 weeks without specific treatment. Postpartum depression (option B) lasts longer than 2 weeks and can have more severe symptoms, while postpartum psychosis (option D) is a rare, but serious, medical emergency that requires treatment with antipsychotics, lithium, and/or antidepressants. Option C is incorrect because the patient did not meet the criteria for a major depressive episode.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of crying and feeling exhausted are consistent with postpartum “blues”, which is a common condition affecting up to 80% of new mothers. The symptoms are self-limited and do not meet criteria for depression or psychosis. The patient denies any changes in concentration or suicidal thoughts which rules out major depressive episode and postpartum psychosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and history suggest postpartum blues, which is a mild and self-limited form of mood disturbance that occurs in up to 80% of women after giving birth. Postpartum depression (B), major depressive episode (C), and postpartum psychosis (D) are more severe conditions with different symptoms and treatment options. The patient's symptoms do not suggest any of these outcomes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms are consistent with postpartum "blues" which occurs in up to 80% of women after delivery. It often resolves on its own within a few days to 2 weeks without any treatment. No other option fits the patient's symptoms and history.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient exhibits symptoms of postpartum “blues”, which is a common mood disturbance that occurs in the first few days up to 2 weeks after childbirth. The symptoms are usually self-limited and do not require treatment. Postpartum depression usually occurs within the first few weeks to months after delivery and lasts longer than 2 weeks. Major depressive episode and postpartum psychosis are more severe forms of depression and are less likely based on the patient’s presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing "baby blues," which are common mood swings and emotional changes that occur within the first few days to weeks after giving birth. Symptoms are self-limited and usually resolve within a few days to two weeks. Option B, postpartum depression, typically develops within the first few months after delivery and can last up to a year or more. Option C, a major depressive episode, is characterized by changes in mood, energy, and activity levels and requires treatment with medication and therapy. Option D, postpartum psychosis, is a rare but serious condition that requires immediate treatment with antipsychotics, lithium, and/or antidepressants. None of the symptoms described in the stem suggest this diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms are consistent with postpartum "blues," which is a self-limited condition that typically resolves within 2 weeks. Postpartum depression is characterized by a persistently depressed mood and can last for several months or longer. Major depressive episode requires a history of at least one episode of depression before pregnancy, and postpartum psychosis is a rare but serious condition that requires immediate intervention. The patient in this scenario does not exhibit symptoms that suggest either of these diagnoses.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms are consistent with postpartum "blues," which are common within the first few days after delivery and are self-limited. Postpartum depression typically presents within the first few weeks after delivery and can last for several months. Major depressive episode has symptoms that persist for at least two weeks and require treatment with psychotherapy and/or medication. Postpartum psychosis is a rare but serious condition that requires immediate medical attention and treatment with medications such as antipsychotics, lithium, and/or antidepressants.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing symptoms consistent with postpartum "blues", which is a self-limited condition that affects up to 70% of new mothers. This condition typically resolves within 2 weeks without treatment. Postpartum depression (option B) is characterized by more severe and persistent symptoms, and can last for several months. Major depressive episode (option C) is a more severe form of depression that can occur at any time, not just after childbirth, and is associated with a high risk of recurrence. Postpartum psychosis (option D) is a rare and severe psychiatric disorder that requires immediate treatment with antipsychotics, lithium, and/or antidepressants. None of the patient's symptoms suggest this diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms are consistent with postpartum "blues," which is common and self-limited lasting up to two weeks after childbirth. Postpartum depression is more severe and persistent, lasting at least 2 weeks and up to 6 months if untreated. A major depressive episode lasts longer and requires treatment. Postpartum psychosis is less common and requires immediate treatment with antipsychotics, lithium, and/or antidepressants. The patient does not exhibit symptoms of psychosis, suicidal thoughts, or changes in concentration, so A is the most appropriate answer.
